newsitem.title: UK: Police said to warn British sports stars on bombs.
newsitem.headline: Police said to warn British sports stars on bombs.

text.p: British police were on Monday advising potential victims targetted by suspected Danish neo-Nazis in a planned letter bomb campaign against sports personalities in mixed-race marriages.

Danish officials said a group of seven neo-Nazis were held at the weekend after police seized three letter bombs -- explosive devices hidden in video cassettes -- posted in Sweden to addresses in London.

British newspapers said that among those targetted were former heavyweight boxing champion Frank Bruno, swimmer turned television presenter Sharron Davies and England international footballer Paul Ince.
Bruno and Ince are black while their wives, Laura and Claire, are white. Davies is white and married to black athlete Derek Redmond.
Redmond said: "Obviously, it is upsetting, but it's not the first time something like this has happened. Unfortunately it is unlikely to be the last," he told the Daily Mail.
Danish police cautioned, however, that they had no evidence to support reports that British sports personalities in mixed-race marriages were the targets.
"There is nothing in our material referring to sportspeople in Great Britain," Ove Dahl, assistant chief of the Copenhagen police murder squad, told the Danish news agency Ritzau.

The comment caused surprise as Danish Justice Minister Frank Jensen had on Sunday told the daily Berlingske Tidende: "They were to be received by people known as left-leaning and by sportspeople married to blacks."
Jensen was travelling on Monday and an aide was trying to reach him for clarification.
British police would not confirm or deny the newspaper reports and said only: "Police are liaising with the intended recipients, who are being given crime prevention advice."
This included tips on how to recognise a letter or parcel bomb and what to do if one arrived in the mail.

A Copenhagen court early on Sunday remanded five Danes in custody for 27 days and freed two on bail after a series of raids and the retrieval of three letter bombs posted in Sweden to addresses in London.
The Daily Mail said a journalist working for Britain's Channel Four television was also an intended recipient.
Danish police were alerted to the group's activities by Britain's Scotland Yard through a police intelligence clearing house in Wiesbaden, Germany, the Daily Mail said.

Danish police found neo-Nazi literature and symbols in Saturday's raids in Copenhagen and in a seaside village north of the capital along with detonators, a nine-millimetre pistol and a pump-action shotgun.
The only one of the seven to be named by police, 26-year-old Thomas Derry Nakaba, shot a policeman in the groin as detectives forced their way into his home.
Danish police are clearly unhappy with their Swedish colleagues' decision to detonate the three letter bombs but hope that laboratory tests may still reveal useful evidence.
"It's certainly bad news that they blew them up but at the moment I don't think it is of very great significance," Dahl said.
